stories.title: The Glacier That Healed a Marriage
stories.intended_reader: Couples struggling in their marriage or seeking reconnection
stories.core_insight: Radiance's glass-wall design and Alaska itineraries create space for broken marriages to breathe and heal
stories.markdown:
**We'd become strangers in the same house.**

Twenty-six years married, but we hadn't really connected in three months. We'd learned to exist side by side without truly seeing each other.

The [Alaska cruise](/ports.html) on Radiance was my wife's idea. "Glass walls everywhere," she said, reading reviews. "Nothing to hide behind." I thought she was being poetic. She was being prophetic.

Radiance's design forced honesty. Floor-to-ceiling windows in our [balcony cabin](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html), glass elevators exposing us as we moved through the ship, the Centrum's transparent architecture making every space feel open. You can't hide on a ship made of glass.

At Hubbard Glacier, we stood at the Deck 11 viewing area — silent, separate, watching ancient ice calve into the sea. Thunder echoed across the water. My wife whispered Ecclesiastes: "*There is a time to tear down and a time to build, a time to weep and a time to laugh.*"

"Which time is this?" I asked.

"Both," she said, and took my hand for the first time in ninety days.

That night at [Chops Grille](/restaurants/chops.html), we didn't talk about fixing everything. We talked about the glacier, the salmon at [Windjammer](/restaurants/windjammer.html), the pianist in the [Centrum](/ships.html). Small things. Safe things. The things we'd stopped sharing.

By the last night, we renewed our vows unofficially at the glass elevators, watching the Inside Passage slide past. Not because everything was fixed — but because glass walls teach you that brokenness doesn't have to be hidden to be healed.

**The lesson:** Radiance's transparent design is a metaphor. Marriage needs windows, not walls. See [our marriage restoration cruise guide](/articles.html) and [packing list for couples](/packing-lists/couples-cruise.html).

stories.title: The Boy Who Couldn't Speak Found His Voice
stories.intended_reader: Parents of nonverbal or autistic children seeking therapeutic travel options
stories.core_insight: Radiance's predictable layout and sensory-friendly design help neurodiverse children thrive
stories.markdown:
**Eight years old, minimally verbal, and our first vacation in four years.**

Ethan's autism meant routines ruled our lives. New environments triggered meltdowns that could last hours. Our therapist suggested water — "Oceans have rhythm. Autistic brains respond to rhythm."

Radiance's layout saved us. Unlike mega-ships with confusing neighborhoods, Radiance stacks decks vertically in logical order. Ethan mapped it in two days: elevators here, [Windjammer](/restaurants/windjammer.html) there, pool deck up, cabin down. Predictability = peace.

The glass walls became his obsession. He'd stand at the Centrum watching the elevators rise and fall, pressing his hands against the windows, tracking movement. Sensory input without sensory overload. The [Solarium](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html) became his sanctuary — warm, enclosed glass, gentle water features, soft light.

Day five, at Tracy Arm Fjord, Ethan stood at the floor-to-ceiling windows and said his longest sentence ever: "God made ice mountains for us to see Him better."

I dropped my coffee. My wife sobbed. The couple next to us — veterans of Radiance's Alaska run — high-fived Ethan without making eye contact (they understood sensory boundaries).

The [crew](/ships.html) adapted without us asking. The [Chops Grille](/restaurants/chops.html) server brought Ethan's chicken plain and early. The youth staff let him line up toy boats in silent rows while other kids played loudly. Nobody forced, nobody fixed, nobody pitied.

**The truth:** Not every ship understands neurodiversity. Radiance's logical layout, natural light, and predictable rhythm gave our son room to be himself. See [our special needs cruise planning guide](/accessibility.html) and [sensory-friendly packing list](/packing-lists/special-needs-cruise.html).

stories.title: Grandpa's Last Alaska
stories.intended_reader: Families making final trips with terminally ill loved ones
stories.core_insight: Radiance creates space for families to make sacred memories before saying goodbye
stories.markdown:
**The oncologist gave him four months. He wanted to spend one at sea.**

Grandpa had sailed Alaska seven times — all on Radiance. "She's the right size," he'd say. "Not too big to get lost. Not too small to get bored." This would be number eight. And the last.

We booked an [accessible cabin](/accessibility.html) with a balcony. Grandpa spent mornings there wrapped in blankets, watching the Inside Passage slide past, coffee in his shaking hands. He'd quote Psalms: "*The sea is His, for He made it, and His hands formed the dry land.*"

The glass elevators became our daily ritual. Three generations riding silently to Deck 11, Grandpa in his wheelchair, watching mountains rise from the sea through floor-to-ceiling windows. "This is my cathedral," he whispered at Glacier Bay. "This is where I meet God."

At [Giovanni's Table](/restaurants/giovannis.html), the server who'd served Grandpa on two previous sailings recognized him. She brought him tiramisu "on the house" and held his hand while he prayed over the meal. She cried when he blessed her by name.

Grandpa passed six weeks after we docked. But at his funeral, his grandchildren didn't talk about cancer. They talked about Radiance — the glaciers, the whales, the way Grandpa laughed at the towel animals, the Scripture he'd quote at every port. The ship gave us a final gift: not more time, but *better* time.

**The lesson:** Death doesn't wait. But Radiance's [accessible design](/accessibility.html) and intimate scale mean you can travel with dignity even in final days. See [our end-of-life travel guide](/articles.html) for making sacred memories.

stories.title: The Widow Who Learned to Laugh Again
stories.intended_reader: Solo travelers processing loss and learning to live again
stories.core_insight: Radiance offers gentle community for widows and widowers finding peace after loss
stories.markdown:
**I booked the cruise one year after Michael died.**

Everyone said it was too soon. "You've never traveled [solo](/solo.html)," my daughter protested. But Michael and I had planned this Alaska trip for fifteen years. I couldn't let his death kill the dream too.

Radiance felt manageable. At 2,466 guests, it wasn't the anonymous chaos of mega-ships or the claustrophobic intimacy of small expedition boats. I could be alone without being lonely. I could grieve without being watched.

The first morning, I sat in the [Solarium](/ships.html) reading 1 Thessalonians 4: "*Brothers and sisters, we do not want you to be uninformed about those who sleep in death, so that you do not grieve like the rest of mankind, who have no hope.*" I had hope. But grief still felt crushing.

At [Windjammer](/restaurants/windjammer.html), a crew member noticed me eating alone and seated me with two other women — both widows, both on their first solo cruise. We didn't plan it. God did. We spent the week sharing tables, sharing stories, sharing the strange new weight of wedding rings worn out of memory, not marriage.

At Mendenhall Glacier, standing at Radiance's glass walls watching ice older than nations, I laughed for the first time in a year. A real laugh. A seal had photobombed someone's selfie. Silly. Ridiculous. Healing.

Michael would have loved that seal.

**The truth:** Grief doesn't have a timeline. But on Radiance, surrounded by widows who understood and creation that declared God's faithfulness, I learned to breathe differently. See [our solo cruise guide](/solo.html) and [widow's travel packing list](/packing-lists.html).

stories.title: The Veteran's Peace
stories.intended_reader: Veterans, first responders, or trauma survivors seeking therapeutic travel
stories.core_insight: Radiance's ocean-forward design and gentle rhythm offer respite for traumatized souls
stories.markdown:
**I hadn't slept through the night in eleven years.**

Two tours in Afghanistan, three IEDs, more firefights than I can count. The VA therapist said water might help. "Rhythmic, predictable, non-threatening," she explained. "Your nervous system needs that."

Radiance's [balcony cabin](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html) faced nothing but ocean. Floor-to-ceiling windows showing endless horizon. No sudden movements. No hidden threats. Just water and sky meeting in infinite peace. I left the curtains open and slept nine hours straight. First time since Kandahar.

The [Solarium](/ships.html) became my sanctuary. Glass-enclosed, warm, quiet. Mornings I'd sit there with coffee from [Café Latte-tudes](/restaurants.html), reading Philippians 4: "*And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.*"

I met another vet at the glass elevators — Marine, Iraq, same haunted eyes. We didn't swap war stories. We swapped silence. Watched glaciers calve. Counted whales. Breathed together. Brothers who'd seen too much learning to see beauty again.

At [Chops Grille](/restaurants/chops.html), the server asked about my challenge coin on the table. When I explained, he brought his own — Army, Desert Storm. We prayed over the meal together, two warriors grateful to be home, grateful to be alive, grateful for ships that sail through calm waters.

**The lesson:** PTSD doesn't vanish at sea. But Radiance's predictable rhythm, endless ocean views, and veteran-friendly community helped me breathe without hypervigilance. See [our veteran travel guide](/articles.html) and [PTSD-aware packing list](/packing-lists.html).

stories.title: The Cancer Survivor's Victory Lap
stories.intended_reader: Cancer survivors or families celebrating remission and recovery milestones
stories.core_insight: Radiance provides joyful space to celebrate survival and reclaim life after medical trauma
stories.markdown:
**Five years cancer-free. We were done just surviving.**

Ovarian cancer had stolen my forties — surgeries, chemo, scans, fear. But at fifty-one, I was NED (no evidence of disease), and my husband insisted: "We're going to Alaska. We're going to *live*."

Radiance's mid-size design meant I could explore without exhaustion. My stamina was still rebuilding — long walks through mega-ship corridors would've wrecked me. But Radiance? Manageable. [Windjammer](/restaurants/windjammer.html) to cabin: three minutes. Deck 4 to Deck 11: one elevator. Rest when needed. Move when able.

The [balcony](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html) saved me on hard days. When crowds felt overwhelming or fatigue hit, I could retreat without missing the journey. Watch Alaska slide past from my own private refuge. Cancer had taught me to honor my body's limits. Radiance's design respected them.

We renewed our vows at Glacier Bay — unofficially, just us at the glass walls. "In sickness and in health" now meant something fierce. We'd lived the sickness. This was the health part. This was the *victory*.

At the [Chef's Table](/restaurants.html), when the sommelier learned our story, he brought champagne. "To beating the odds," he toasted. I wept into my lobster bisque — not from grief, but from wonder. I was *here*. Tasting things. Feeling things. Alive.

**The truth:** Surviving isn't the same as thriving. But Radiance gave us space to celebrate being alive without pretending recovery is linear. See [our post-cancer cruise guide](/articles.html) and [medical recovery packing list](/packing-lists.html).

stories.title: The Prodigal Son Returns
stories.intended_reader: Families navigating estrangement or attempting reconciliation
stories.core_insight: Radiance provides neutral ground for fractured families to try healing
stories.markdown:
**I hadn't spoken to my dad in six years.**

Theological disagreements that became weapons. Church splits that split families. I walked away from the faith, and Dad walked away from me. But when Mom's cancer went into remission, she begged: "One week. Just give me one week together."

She booked Radiance for all of us — me, my partner, my brother, Dad.

The first two days were ice. Dad wouldn't make eye contact at [Windjammer](/restaurants/windjammer.html). I sat as far from him as geometry allowed. Mom looked heartbroken. My partner asked if we should disembark at Juneau.

But Radiance's glass walls forced something unexpected: transparency. At Glacier Bay, we all stood at the same windows watching ice thunder into the sea. Dad quoted Job: "*From whose womb comes the ice? Who gives birth to the frost from the heavens?*"

I answered without thinking: "*When the waters become hard as stone, when the surface of the deep is frozen?*" First words we'd exchanged in six years. Scripture we both knew by heart.

That night at [Giovanni's Table](/restaurants/giovannis.html), Dad prayed over the meal. He included my partner by name. Not acceptance — not yet. But acknowledgment. Movement. Grace.

By week's end, we weren't fixed. But we were *talking*. The [Solarium](/ships.html) became our meeting place — neutral ground where we could sit in silence or share small truths without the pressure of resolution.

**The lesson:** Reconciliation isn't one conversation. It's a hundred small steps. Radiance's intimate scale and transparent design gave us space to try. See [our family reconciliation travel guide](/articles.html).

stories.title: Learning to Sabbath
stories.intended_reader: Pastors, missionaries, ministry leaders battling burnout
stories.core_insight: Radiance's unhurried pace teaches burnt-out servants to receive rather than give
stories.markdown:
**Twenty-eight years in ministry. I'd forgotten how to stop.**

My elders forced the sabbatical. "You're running on fumes," they said. "Take Radiance. Alaska. Three weeks. No sermons. No counseling. No email." I protested that the sheep needed a shepherd. They reminded me that Jesus is the Good Shepherd, and I'm just hired help.

The first days I paced Radiance's Promenade Deck like a caged animal. Ministry had trained me to *produce*. But cruise ships demand you receive. Meals appear in the [main dining room](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html#dining-card). Entertainment happens whether you attend or not. The ocean moves without your effort.

On day four, in the [Solarium](/ships.html), I opened my Bible. Not to study — to *listen*. Psalm 46: "*Be still, and know that I am God.*" The Spirit whispered: "Let Me shepherd you."

I sat there five hours doing nothing while Radiance carried me through the Inside Passage. No sermon prep. No crisis intervention. Just a burned-out pastor being pastored by the Chief Shepherd.

At [Chops Grille](/restaurants/chops.html), I thanked the server by name, learned her story, prayed with her when she mentioned her sick father. Not pastoral duty — pastoral *overflow*. Rest had refilled what ministry emptied.

When I returned to my church, I preached from Exodus 33: Moses in the cleft of the rock, hidden while God's glory passed by. "Sometimes," I told my congregation, "the most spiritual thing you can do is let God hide you in the ship's hull while He does His work."

**The lesson:** You can't pour from an empty cup. Radiance taught me Sabbath isn't laziness — it's trust. See [our minister's sabbatical guide](/articles.html) and [pastoral rest packing list](/packing-lists.html).

stories.title: The Stroke Survivor Who Walked Again
stories.intended_reader: Stroke survivors or families supporting recovery from neurological events
stories.core_insight: Radiance's accessible design and patient crew accommodate post-stroke recovery
stories.markdown:
**Eight months post-stroke, right side paralyzed, and I wanted to see glaciers.**

My neurologist said I was crazy. My daughter said I was brave. I said I was *alive*, and that deserved celebrating. She booked an [accessible cabin](/accessibility.html) on Radiance without asking my permission.

The cabin was a revelation. Grab bars positioned exactly where my functioning left hand could reach them. Roll-in shower wide enough for my wheelchair. Emergency call buttons everywhere. The crew noted my mobility limits without making me feel broken.

At [Chops Grille](/restaurants/chops.html), the server automatically placed my water glass on my left side — the side that still worked. At [Windjammer](/restaurants/windjammer.html), staff helped cut my food without me asking, then disappeared so I could maintain dignity.

But the real miracle happened at the glass walls. Physical therapy had been clinical, depressing. But watching Alaska's majesty slide past through floor-to-ceiling windows, I *wanted* to stand. Not because doctors demanded it — because creation called me.

I shuffled from wheelchair to walker, walker to railing, railing to window. Ten feet. Then fifteen. By week's end, I walked the full Promenade Deck with my daughter's arm tucked in mine. The [Solarium](/ships.html) staff applauded when we completed the loop.

"See, Dad?" my daughter whispered, crying. "You're not done yet."

**The lesson:** Strokes don't have to end travel. Radiance's accessible design meant I could focus on recovery, not logistics. See [our post-stroke travel guide](/articles.html) and [accessible cruise packing list](/packing-lists/accessible-cruise.html).

stories.title: The Anxious Traveler's First Cruise
stories.intended_reader: First-time cruisers or travelers with anxiety disorders
stories.core_insight: Radiance's mid-size design and transparent architecture ease anxious travelers into cruising
stories.markdown:
**Generalized anxiety disorder meant I hadn't left my county in nine years.**

Crowds triggered panic attacks. New environments paralyzed me. But my therapist insisted: "Controlled exposure. Predictable routines. Start small." She suggested a cruise. I laughed until I hyperventilated.

But my sister researched and chose Radiance specifically. "Mid-size," she explained. "Glass walls everywhere so you never feel trapped. Straightforward layout. Alaska itinerary means focus stays on scenery, not ship chaos."

The first night I couldn't breathe. Too many people at [Windjammer](/restaurants/windjammer.html). Too many sounds. My sister walked me to the [Solarium](/ships.html) — glass-enclosed, quiet, warm. "Safe space," she said. "Come here when it's too much."

I lived in that Solarium the first three days. Watching water. Reading Psalms. Praying the anxiety away. The crew learned my name, brought me tea, never pressured.

Day four, I made it to Deck 11 for Glacier Bay. Stood at the floor-to-ceiling windows surrounded by strangers, and didn't panic. Watched ancient ice calve into the sea and quoted Isaiah 43: "*When you pass through the waters, I will be with you.*"

By week's end, I ate dinner in the [main dining room](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html#dining-card) — surrounded by people, participating in conversation, laughing at our server's jokes. My sister took a photo to show my therapist: proof that prison doors can open.

**The truth:** Anxiety doesn't vanish at sea. But Radiance's transparent, predictable design gave me room to breathe and grow. See [our anxious traveler's guide](/articles.html) and [anxiety-aware packing list](/packing-lists.html).

stories.title: Glass Walls and Ocean Views
stories.intended_reader: Travelers considering Radiance who value ocean views and mid-sized ships
stories.core_insight: Radiance's glass-wall design creates an intimate, ocean-connected experience on a mid-sized ship
stories.markdown:
**The first thing you notice about Radiance is the glass.**

Floor-to-ceiling windows line the promenades. Glass elevators climb the outside of the ship, offering unobstructed views as you rise eleven decks above the waterline. Even the [dining rooms](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html#dining-card) feel connected to the sea—natural light floods in during breakfast, and at dinner you watch the horizon shift colors as the sun sets.

This isn't a ship built to distract you from the ocean. It's designed for travelers who *want* to watch the water, not just be on it. When you sail through Alaska's Inside Passage or glide past Sydney's harbor at dawn, those glass walls transform from architectural detail to front-row seats.

At about 2,466 guests (double occupancy), Radiance feels mid-sized—big enough for variety (you'll find [Royal Caribbean's](/cruise-lines/royal-caribbean.html) signature entertainment and specialty dining), small enough that you won't get lost finding your cabin or spend half your sea day navigating endless corridors. The layout is straightforward: decks stack vertically, no confusing neighborhood zones or hidden venues tucked behind waterslides.

If you've sailed mega-ships like [Oasis](/ships/rcl/oasis-of-the-seas.html) or [Icon class](/ships/rcl/icon-of-the-seas.html), Radiance will feel intimate—almost quiet by comparison. If you're coming from smaller ships, it still offers Royal Caribbean's reliability without overwhelming you with options.

stories.title: What Works Well on Radiance
stories.intended_reader: Travelers deciding if Radiance's features match their cruise priorities
stories.core_insight: Radiance excels at ocean-forward design and straightforward navigation without overwhelming crowds
stories.markdown:
**Ocean-forward design.** The glass walls aren't just aesthetic—they fundamentally change how you experience the ship. You're reading in the Solarium and look up to see a pod of dolphins keeping pace. You're waiting for an elevator and catch the first glimpse of a glacier calving in the distance. The architecture keeps pulling your attention outward. [Alaska sailings](/ports.html) especially benefit from this: Radiance was *made* for scenic cruising.

**Mid-size navigation.** You can walk from bow to stern in under ten minutes. Elevators are rarely crowded—no seven-stop waits like the mega-ships. The [Windjammer buffet](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html#dining-card) has actual breathing room at breakfast; you're not playing Tetris with your tray. On embarkation day, you don't feel like you're boarding a floating city. You feel like you're boarding a *ship*.

**Classic Royal Caribbean reliability.** Main dining room with attentive service. [Chops Grille](/restaurants.html) when you want a proper steak. Solid entertainment—Broadway-style shows, live music, comedians who've been doing this for years. Familiar layout that doesn't require a map app to find the pool. If you've sailed [Royal Caribbean](/cruise-lines/royal-caribbean.html) before, Radiance won't surprise you—but it won't disappoint either. It's the ship equivalent of a well-worn leather jacket: comfortable, dependable, exactly what you need.

**Global itineraries.** Radiance has sailed everywhere: Alaska in summer, Caribbean in winter, Australia, Asia, transatlantic repositioning cruises where you wake up to open ocean for days. It's a ship built for *going places*, not just circling the same seven-night loops forever. If you're the type who picks cruises for the itinerary first and ship second, Radiance often ends up on your shortlist.

stories.title: What to Know Before You Book
stories.intended_reader: Travelers setting realistic expectations about Radiance's age and amenities
stories.core_insight: Radiance is a 2001 ship offering classic reliability over cutting-edge amenities — choose it for itinerary, not thrills
stories.markdown:
**This is a 2001 ship.** Radiance entered service before neighborhood layouts, FlowRider surf simulators, or robot bartenders became standard. It's been refurbished—you won't find peeling paint or worn carpets—but don't expect cutting-edge tech or the newest venues. The TVs in your cabin won't stream Netflix. The pools are functional, not Instagram-worthy. The fitness center has treadmills and free weights, not Peloton bikes or juice bars.

**Smaller dining variety.** You'll find the essentials ([main dining room](/ships/rcl/radiance-of-the-seas.html#dining-card), Windjammer, [Chops Grille](/restaurants.html), Chef's Table, a few bars), but not the 20+ venue spread of [Oasis](/ships/rcl/oasis-of-the-seas.html) or [Icon class](/ships/rcl/icon-of-the-seas.html). If you're the type who needs a different restaurant every night, Radiance will feel limiting by day four. If you're fine repeating favorites and value consistency over novelty, you'll be perfectly happy.

**Quieter vibe.** Families sail Radiance, but the ship attracts more couples and [solo travelers](/solo.html) than kid-heavy mega-ships. The pool deck at 2pm on a sea day has people reading books, not kids cannonballing every thirty seconds. Evening entertainment leans toward live music and theater, not high-energy deck parties. If you want calm, you'll find it. If you thrive on constant energy and activity, you might feel like something's missing.

**Itinerary over amenities.** If you're choosing Radiance, you're probably choosing it for *where* it goes—[Alaska's glaciers](/ports.html), Australia's Great Barrier Reef, transatlantic crossings, repositioning cruises that call at ports the big ships skip—rather than onboard thrills. The ship is the vehicle, not the destination. And that's exactly how Radiance is designed to work.

stories.title: Who Radiance Fits Best
stories.intended_reader: Travelers comparing Radiance to other Royal Caribbean ships
stories.core_insight: Radiance suits travelers who prioritize scenic itineraries, quieter ships, and ocean views over mega-ship amenities
stories.markdown:
**You'll probably love Radiance if:**
- You want panoramic ocean views and glass-wall design—the kind of ship where you actually *notice* the ocean
- You prefer [mid-sized ships](/ships.html) you can navigate easily without a map or asking crew members for directions three times a day
- You're sailing scenic routes (Alaska, Australia, transatlantic repositioning) where the destination matters more than the ship's Instagram factor
- You value calm sea days over non-stop activities—you're perfectly happy with a book, a deck chair, and the sound of the waves
- You've sailed [Royal Caribbean](/cruise-lines/royal-caribbean.html) before and trust their reliability: familiar food quality, solid service, no unpleasant surprises
- You're a couple or [solo traveler](/solo.html) who doesn't need kid-friendly chaos to enjoy a cruise

**You might prefer another ship if:**
- You want cutting-edge tech and newest venues: FlowRiders, VR experiences, robot bartenders, multi-story waterslides (try [Quantum](/ships/rcl/quantum-of-the-seas.html), [Oasis](/ships/rcl/oasis-of-the-seas.html), or [Icon class](/ships/rcl/icon-of-the-seas.html))
- You need [20+ dining options](/restaurants.html) and endless activities—a different venue every night, packed daily schedules, constant entertainment
- You're traveling with kids who want *excitement*: waterslides, laser tag, surf simulators, arcade games, non-stop action
- You prefer neighborhood layouts to traditional deck stacking—you like the idea of Central Park promenades or divided zones like the mega-ships offer
- You're looking for the newest, shiniest thing—Radiance is comfortable, not cutting-edge

**The honest truth:** Radiance isn't flashy, but it's dependable. It's the ship you choose because you *get* what it's trying to be: a floating base camp for beautiful itineraries, designed for travelers who'd rather watch glaciers calve into the ocean than ride a surf simulator. If you sail Radiance and complain it's not as exciting as [Icon of the Seas](/ships/rcl/icon-of-the-seas.html), you've misunderstood the assignment.

See [sister ships](/ships/rcl/brilliance-of-the-seas.html) like Brilliance, [Serenade](/ships/rcl/serenade-of-the-seas.html), and [Jewel](/ships/rcl/jewel-of-the-seas.html) for nearly identical layouts and similar vibes—same glass-wall philosophy, same mid-sized intimacy, different itineraries.
